posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked:
To celebrate the start of summer Dephi, I'd like to highlight the concerns about major CAD software developers not porting their legacy software to modern web-based platforms. Established programs like SolidWorks, Inventor, and Creo primarily lack cloud features, yet this is the only significant limitation. Newer CAD programs developed by these software's creators address collaboration and cloud storage issues but often restructure the CAD process unnecessarily. The absence of robust cloud capabilities drives users to adopt these new platforms, albeit with drawbacks limiting their utility and complicating workflows.

Key cloud features lacking in older CAD programs include effective file sharing, seamless cross-platform viewing, and browser-based editing. For file sharing, a reliable, built-in cloud storage system with intuitive integration is essential, avoiding fragmented setups across multiple programs. Cross-platform viewing should allow easy access to CAD files via links or mobile apps without requiring extensive 2D drawing packages. Browser-based editing offers flexibility for engineers accustomed to dedicated tools, though its benefits are somewhat diminished compared to traditional CAD environments.

Despite these advantages, newer CAD programs introduce trade-offs such as overly complex UIs, limited feature sets, and obscured mathematical underpinnings. They also risk expanding beyond CAD into unrelated areas like CAM, FEA, or communication platforms, complicating user adoption. Additionally, monolithic file structures separating part, assembly, and drawing files introduce unnecessary layers of complexity, hindering efficient collaboration.

A desirable solution would be a browser-integrated CAD system seamlessly embedded within existing platforms like SolidWorks or Inventor, offering the simplicity of native CAD tools combined with cloud accessibility. This approach could potentially surpass competitors like Onshape and 3DExperience, addressing the frustrations faced by engineers who prefer convenience over broader ecosystems.

posts.name: Christopher149
posts.cooked:
Browser-based editing: I think this is the least important of the 3 basic cloud features, but it is a huge asset in education where people are likely using computers that were not purchased with CAD in mind. 

For us, it’s convenient to use the classroom laptop (which is the school’s, not ours) to bring up CAD on the projector, so the browser access is very convenient to not need to install anything. At the same time, there was a brief outage this year that was annoying, but is also the first outage I’ve been aware of.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FRC857 lead mentor / FTC10723+13284+15270 lead mentor

posts.name: Andrew Torrance
posts.cooked: 254 is strongly considering switching to Onshape for the first time after 25 years due to the issues with Solidworks PDM and how 3DExperience is also too annoying to set up (have to have students create accounts and submit emails? come on).

posts.name: Zachary
posts.cooked: The good news is that the guy who made SolidWorks did create a browser-based CAD! It’s called Onshape.

posts.name: Pizzatc
posts.cooked: Someone must have hacked his account.

posts.name: Jonathan Mi
posts.cooked: Solidworks did try to create an online CAD experience, it’s called xDesign. As a long time Solidworks user and having tried xDesign first hand, to say that it’s… lacking would be an understatement.

posts.name: Nick.kremer
posts.cooked: One of us. On a more serious note, Onshape excels in FIRST Robotics Competition due to its good performance without high-end laptops, baked-in multibody design, minimal file management overhead, easy versioning, simple sharing of links, access to libraries like MKCAD and FRCDesign.org, and robust FRC-specific features via featurescripts. Nothing else matches this level right now. I don’t look back after switching.

posts.name: Matthew K
posts.cooked: I really like the idea. The only thing I don’t like about browser-based CAD is that I need an internet connection. What if I was doing CAD on a plane, or the power cut out, but I still had my laptop?

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: The only drawback once you learn how to use OnShape is no CAM. But that’s not a problem for us yet. While it’s slow going, it’s coming soon. They’re only going to ship it to enterprises now because it’s still in beta. I’m a bit surprised it’s taking longer than expected since the announcement, but like video games, I’d rather have a fully developed and polished product than a half-done one. Plus, everyone gets it for free.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Its BURNIE. not Bernie. And certainly not Burn-E.

posts.name: Patrick
posts.cooked: Yeah, I also like having access to CAD in the pits where internet is usually poor at best. Hence, I’d like some browser-based integration for an established desktop CAD program. Let everyone who wants to download everything so they can work offline.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked: I'd like to complain about every major CAD software developer not porting their old software into the internet age. I don’t have access to OnShape’s source. But this is much easier said than done. I suspect this would basically be a complete rewrite and a major re-architect. Onshape likely uses a combo of client side and backend side processing to make it friendly on every platform. I’m guessing of SolidWorks hasn’t done this by now they’ve decided its just not a market they are interested in for that particular product. Or they are but it’ll be a while.

Based on a decade or more experience with other Dassault Systèmes software, I doubt they will be the ones who grant your wish. Solid Works reminds me of much of their other software: well-made but they are slow to change and adapt. When you have big, regulated customers, they often aren't interested in deep or fast changes to things. Competition is good.

Making cloud versions of legacy software doesn’t always work out well. There are too many cases where a browser-based interface with the same name lacks the necessary functionality compared to the original. Comparing Microsoft Word as desktop-native software with Google Docs as cloud-native, Word still holds more power in terms of pure word processing. However, when they added cloud features to Word, it became clunky to collaborate, and comments introduced weird spaces in the text. Unreliable OneDrive integration is another issue. I’m not entirely sure why these problems, especially the comments, exist, but I think they’re due to retrofittng software for tasks it wasn’t meant for initially, leading to suboptimal infrastructure.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Doubling the current limit does not make it work.

posts.name: Nathan
posts.cooked: My idea is that Onshape could allow local editing without internet access, like Google Docs does. However, I'm not sure how this would function technically.

posts.name: Ben_Lerner
posts.cooked:
Cross-platform file viewing is something I’ve been exploring lately, and I want to share my experience with eDrawing. We started using it this year, though it doesn’t fully solve the issues you mentioned. However, it’s still a valuable tool based on my hands-on experience. Interestingly, it has a mobile app available for download, which surprisingly works exceptionally well. For instance, I’ve successfully opened and viewed heavy assemblies, like our elevator and gripper assembly, directly from my iPhone.

Additionally, eDrawing compresses SolidWorks files significantly, making it easier to share them with others. It also offers handy features, such as encrypting files so viewers can’t measure anything, and allows importing parts as STL files. Another great aspect is how similar its desktop interface is to SolidWorks, maintaining functionality for tasks like measuring.

The desktop app is free, but the iPhone version costs around $5. If you find it enjoyable, there’s no reason not to purchase it. Overall, I’d recommend trying it out unless you have specific reasons against it.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Head of CAD & Strategy lead for team 5951

posts.cooked:
We have used SolidWorks for many years. Last year, we tried 3DExperience, and this year, we switched to OnShape. OnShape has transformed how we design the robot. It’s remarkable that one of our students can create CAD models during lunchtime on their Chromebook, allowing someone at home to modify designs directly for manufacturing.  

SolidWorks is very powerful. However, I believe both XDesign/3DExperience were difficult to use effectively, while OnShape’s tutorials and [Link] along with FRCDesign.org made a significant difference for us.

posts.name: Max Morehead
posts.cooked: I will do it for 77dwvs. The reasons CAD programs aren’t the best is because the TAM is comparatively small (only $12B instead of $120B for word processors, according to some searches). Also, the market is really hard for new entrants, both because CAD programs are difficult to write, so you need a lot of experts, and because the minimum viable product is very large because most of the money is in commercial users already using an existing program. It’s actually pretty surprising to me that Onshape was successful.

Patrick3357: I'm not just talking about CAM or FEA. FEA in most CAD packages is honestly scope creep. If their FEA tools can’t do all of 2D elements, hex elements, give you appropriate mesh control, run basic nonlinear analysis, and run transient analysis, it’s useless as an FEA package because it’s missing some of the most essential features. My answer would be “Go learn ANSYS or some other dedicated FEA package where you actually do the things you want to do.” To my knowledge, SolidWorks has unusable mesh controls while OnShape is missing 2D analysis, nonlinear analysis, and multiple mesh controls.
